newsitem.title: USA: Glazier breaks windows to drum up business.
newsitem.headline: Glazier breaks windows to drum up business.

text.p: A New York glazier and one of his employees were indicted Monday for smashing store-front windows to drum up business, prosecutors said.
Jason Harte, 28, of New Rochelle, N.Y., president of Crystal Glass Co., and salesman Gerry Montello, 34, of Brooklyn, N.Y., are charged with conspiracy, grand larceny and criminal mischief.
"He was smashing glass, now he'll be smashing rocks in prison," Assistant District Attorney Daniel Castleman said in announcing the charges against Harte.

The two men are accused of breaking storefront windows worth more than $155,000 in some of Manhattan's premier shopping areas. The pair allegedly used hammers, slingshots and rocks in a window-smashing campaign that lasted from September 1996 until last month.
Another salesman, Gene Terrance Jones, 24, pleaded guilty June 3 to criminal mischief for breaking a window at a Madison Avenue salon.

Last July, Harte pleaded guilty to breaking more than $1 million worth of windows at such tony Manhattan stores as Cartier and Chanel, law enforcement sources said. He was sentenced to five years probation.
Authorities said the most expensive window broken in the most recent campaign was at a record store in midtown Manhattan. The damage was $91,000.
Harte and Montello face up to seven years in prison if convicted of the charges.
Prosecutors said Harte's seven family glass companies had contracts with the victimised businesses to replace smashed windows.
